etymology.description: semantic: 口 (“mouth”) + phonetic: 刀; originally ‘to call out’ or ‘to serve wine for guests.’ Earliest oracle-bone forms showed hands over a wine vessel, with 口 and 刀 added later.
etymology.interpretation: Mouth provides the idea of vocal calling, while 刀 supplied the sound in Old Chinese. Early depictions of hands over a wine vessel connect the word to presenting wine to guests, which broadened to summoning or inviting, a nuance retained in 招.

examples.chinese: 国王召大臣进宫(國王召大臣進宮)。
examples.english: The king summoned the ministers to the palace.

examples.chinese: 公司明天召集员工开会(公司明天召集員工開會)。
examples.pinyin: Gōngsī míngtiān zhàojí yuángōng kāi huì.
examples.english: The company will convene the employees for a meeting tomorrow.

examples.chinese: 他大声召唤朋友(他大聲召喚朋友)。
examples.english: He loudly called out to his friend.
